Yeah, I'm fine with this. I think the last time we considered our minimum versions was 3-4 years ago, when Trusty still had another year's worth of general support. Current state of distros:

* Bionic: 2.18.4
* Focal: 2.22.0
* Jammy: 2.25.1
* Centos 7: 2.6.0
* Centos 8 Stream: 2.20.0
* Centos 9 Stream: 2.25.1
* Buster: 2.21.0

(So really, I'd be perfectly content to bring this up to 2.6.0.)
Downstream users will, with overwhelming likelihood, use any of those versions, yeah. This is just the most conservative version that should take into account the changes in this patch.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Is there a reason we don't see this applied to master then backported down the stable branches in the normal manner for openstack stable branches? Reminder that this is a wider openstack repo and not purely part of tripleo.

Hi Jonathan

it is because we have different goals for master/wallaby

on master we have centos9 exclusively so we wired up 9 and did an 8 teardown [1]

on wallaby we will have centos8 and centos9 - for a while. Eventually we will kill most of centos8 for wallaby and keep the c9 jobs [2][3]

Generally speaking for zuul.d/ changes we don't often use cherrypick for stable/ branches as we are running different things on different branches.


[1] https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:c8_teardown_master
[2] https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:c9_wallaby_gates
[3] https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:c8_wallaby_teardown

debian-mirror-tools/config/debian/distro.message:
From the manual page for kdump-config, it seems 'linux-image-$(uname -r)-dbg' package is also required.

https://manpages.debian.org/bullseye/kdump-tools/kdump-config.8.en.html
https://www.cyberciti.biz/faq/how-to-on-enable-kernel-crash-dump-on-debian-linux/

There is a package on debian.org that fits the description:

linux-image-amd64-dbg 5.10.84-1

https://packages.debian.org/bullseye/linux-image-amd64-dbg

Yes, I assume that the initial kdump service in ansible which requires 'kdump' just depends on the tool 'kdump'(e.g. /usr/bin/kdump), but does not depend on the kernel package with symbol table 'linux-image-amd64-dbg' though the completed kdump function need the symbol table. If you confirm that 'linux-image-amd64-dbg' is also depended by the kdump.service, I think "linux-image-5.10.0-6-amd64-dbg" should be added in "tools/debian-mirror-tools/config/debian/distro/stx-std.lst",  "stx-std.lst" is for all starlingX packages.

I have investigated kdump and have not found any indication that 'linux-image-amd64-dbg' is a dependency.

It does cite it in this link (https://manpages.debian.org/bullseye/kdump-tools/kdump-config.8.en.html) but says only that "kdump-config can take advantage of the linux-image-$(uname -r)-dbg package"

The package is also very large 800 Mb, increasing to about 5 Gb after installed.

I believe we can move on with this commit and re-evaluate adding linux-image-$(uname -r)-dbg later if evidence comes up that it is necessary.

ironic_inspector/common/ironic.py.message: So instead of using locks and splitting a API query by 5 seconds, why not keep an internal cache that we check first from the last time we queried Ironic for the same information. If the node matches, we avoid a query. If we got it in a previous update, it matches. And *then* wrap the actual act of getting the updated list with a lock

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

ironic_inspector/common/ironic.py.message:
Based on prior comment, maybe lock just this act so only one can occur at one time, and *then* extend it to support an internal in-memory cache which may have just been updated. That way we only do the lookup when we absolutely need to..

*additionally* and I think this is more in-line with the original story. The provision_state can be queried againstiwth Ironic's API[0]. This column in ironic's database *is* indexed, so performing a lookup against an indexed subset will make the overall query return *much* faster. This is likely mutually exclusive from my other idea though. Just a thought.

[0]:https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/baremetal/?expanded=list-nodes-detail

cinder_tempest_plugin/api/volume/test_cr.message:
The f' flag is not support by python 2.7 , not sure if its a good choose here .
We need to assume that this test would run on older versions ....
I can change the prefix creation to use time.time()

The master branches of tempest and its plugins support OpenStack since Ussuri, which means Python 3 only. So the change is fine.

My question is instead: why is the UUID hardcoded? Instead of adding a prefix, can't we just change it? Of course the description (next line) would need to be changed too in that case, as well as the name of the image (line 150) an the name of the volume  (line 159). 

Now, I should have asked this when the test was added instead of simply approving it :) https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder-tempest-plugin/+/737380 but well.
Brian, do you think we can dynamically generate a new UUID here to be used instead of the hardcoded one?

My intention in the original patch was to get the test's idempotent_id into the name of the volume type so that it would be easier to determine where it came from when troubleshooting test failures.  I used the id because while it's ok to change test names, the id is supposed to stay constant.

This id is used in the names of all the volume types and volumes created by this test (except for a volume in the image-volume-cache, whose name I believe will be that of the image_id, which we don't have any control over from the cinder side), so it should be possible to write a maintenance script to go through and clean these things out (although, if something is left in the image-volume-cache, that script will fail).

I'm kind of surprised that we're seeing this issue, because this test should create one volume type and at most two volumes (the second only if the image-volume-cache is enabled).  So it's not like there's a huge list of volumes that must be deleted before the volume type can be deleted during class cleanup. 

Deleting a volume type is a simple database operation, so the only reason it should fail is if there are existing volumes of that type.  While this patch will workaround the previously-existing-volume-type problem, it doesn't address the other cruft that could be left behind:

- the volume created by the test (should be deleted during test teardown)
- the image created by the test (should be deleted during test teardown)
- any other volumes of the test type (would be created if the image-volume-cache is enabled; should be deleted during class teardown)

I would be curious to know if any of this other stuff is piling up on your CI system.

My suggestion is that instead of introducing a random name into the volume_type, you instead use time.time() to give you seconds since the epoch to create the prefix, then use the prefix for all of the items created by this test.  Glance and Cinder both allow names on the order of 255 chars, so name length shouldn't be a problem.  I'd be curious to find out, for example, if images are accumulating in Glance.  Also, this would give you a way to have some kind of scripted cleanup for your CI.

Hi Michal,

I also don't like it so we are off to a good start 😊 Let me try and explain the situation we find ourselves in.

Instead of solely using the ansible `copy` or `template` module to move ceph.conf over to hosts like other roles (like glance) in cinder we use the custom `merge_configs` module.

For some important context: We use the `merge_configs` module as it allows operators to have `config/cinder/ceph.conf` as a global default for all cinder services, but there's a use case for maybe cinder-backup or something to use a different ceph cluster and therefore a different ceph.conf, so we also allow `config/cinder/cinder-backup/ceph.conf` so you can override it per cinder-service if you wish.

Now the core problem is, `merge_configs` module acts like `copy` and *not* `template`. The solutions I saw were:

1. No longer allow a global ceph.conf for all of cinder and make operators have only ceph.conf's for specific cinder-services. The obvious issue with this is that it's a major breaking change, IMHO probably a good change but a disruptive one. One really for a big wide kolla maintainers meeting.

2. Implement optional `template` like functionality into the custom `merge_configs` module. I shyed away from this as it felt a bit daunting and I don't know how complicated it would be.

3. Use the `merge_configs` module still but then not have it do the actual copy to the dest host and leave that to the `template` module which'll eval the jinja for us.

I ended up going with 3. To address the git repo stuff (which is exactly why I'm doing this change, I don't want dynamic ceph stuff inside of a git repo) I created a handler that then deletes the local file see `Clean up {{ item.key }}-ceph.conf` so by the end of a complete run you are left with a clean working directory. I only chose `{{ node_custom_config }}` as I didn't know where else to put such a tmp file.

New patchset incoming asap.

We are not guaranteed have that key locally.

The driving reason for this proposed change is for exactly that. This change enables us to replace the key with a ansible lookup expression.

So instead of:

key = abcd

We might hace:

key = "{{ lookup('hashi_vault', 'secret=secret/client.nova:value url=http://vault.example.com:8200')}}"

Unless you know of another way to resolve that locally instead of what I do of waiting for another module (`template`) to do the work then read it please let me know.

There is one more serious issue with this code than an unnecessary roundtrip - combining "when filtering hosts" and run_once=True may cause the task to be skipped entirely and fail logic, as run_once=True is applied (a host is chosen) before "when". You likely want to do this: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/ansible/builtin/template_lookup.html

sorry, restoring review, I see the question has been answered
what about scale down, scale up? would the parameter also need to be set to existing in that case?

No, it doesn't need to be set. We mandate 3 nodes for A/A, so scale down doesn't really apply. Furthermore, the parameter really only comes into play when a new etcd node is *added* to the cluster (if you just remove a node, it might still be considered a member that is simply no longer available, but that won't affect the other members). And scaling up is handled using the DistributedComputeScaleOut.yaml or DistributedComputeHCIScaleOut.yaml roles, which don't include the etcd service. In short, there should always be 3 nodes running etcd.

deployment/etcd/etcd-container-puppet.ya.message:
I think it should default to existing, to provide idempotent behavior upon minor updates and not cause any turbulence to the nodes in cluster. After etcd cluster is assembled, initial state of the cluster should be `existing`. It could be auto-detected as "new", if 

etcdctl --peers=<all peers> cluster-health

does not return 'cluster is healthy' for the queried node being placed into the all peers list.

The logic makes sense to me:

- either bootstrap idempotently (the impotence makes stack updates not bootstrap)
- or add new members because it already exists (existing is only set on scale up)

I don't believe it's possible to default the initial_cluster_state to "existing" because that would preclude being able to bootstrap the cluster. Only existing members are able to add new members to the cluster (it's a chicken/egg situation). And you can't use "cluster-health" because only a cluster member is able to respond, and there are no members until the cluster is bootstrapped.

If a scale down is run to remove node foo which is a member, then I assume foo is not logically removed from the etcd cluster until this is run. I assume the intention is to ensure any old member is logically removed before adding the new node. I assume also that this portion of code is run during a stack update which is likely during scale up. Is that correct?
Your assumptions are correct. The script is executed as a deploy_steps_task (L283), assuming the condition at L293 is met.
I'm not sure this dir is not CI only? Maybe use /var/log/containers/etcd/ for that?

I don't believe stdouts is CI only, and I would be disappointed if it were because I believe that's where puppet errors are reported. Looking around in my own (non-CI) deployment, I see similar log files from other services, e.g.:

horizon_fix_perms.log
nova_api_ensure_default_cell.log
placement_wait_for_service.log
why do you think it should never fail?

I pondered this quite a lot. In then end, I decided that any issues related to etcd cluster membership (which only happen when replacing a node) should fail the deployment. From experiences working with someone who encountered the membership issue in a lab PoC, it was relatively straightforward to fix up the etcd cluster after the deployment.

That said, I am increasingly confident that the script will not throw an unexpected error, and would be OK removing the failed_when if that remains your recommendation.

Edit:

"any issues related to etcd cluster membership (which only happen when replacing a node) should _NOT_ fail the deployment."
So the Certificate code is essentially unchanged, you're just indenting it further so it can be list_concat'd with the new cluster membership task. Is that right?
Correct. It shifts to accommodate the list_concat at L282.

I think it's more appropriate to have these. A single node also runs wsrep processes.
this seems unnecessary.

We noticed that the single-node version of galera-enabled cluster takes longer time to start and initialize. Our approach to work it around is to disable galera functionality in our deployments. And this readiness.sh does not let us to leverage this approach. So the proposed change makes transparent adjustment to this check. The idea behind this is simple - in case of multiple instances it is vital to have the galera enabled. In case of single instance - galera functional is not a vital part, so the readiness check should succeed even if galera is not enabled.

I think removing wsrep and the other overhead from the replicas = 1 is the right thing to do.

For complicated reasons this doesn't work right, and as it's not useful we don't need it.  If you were to scale (render again, not k8s scale verb) the wsrep status would return and behave as expected.

FWIW, I have labs which are failing right now because of complexities from this very overhead, so I would like to see this merged (or something like it) to address that.

Beyond that, we can talk about what should be done.  If there is contention here I'm happy to setup a call (ping me on irc about this and I'll schedule something).
I am ok to simply "ignore" wsrep status in a single node setup I suppose, it's really kind of useless to check for something that doesn't provide much.
I can confirm we saw issues when scaling down to 1 replica and the clustering overhead would still cause issues.

downgrading my vote a bit... I just worried in case someone manually scale up the deployment, then we lose the checking on wsrep, this may or may not break anything, but I would have like to hear if this is ok for everyone.
LGTM. It does make sense to initiate only where it will be used

Shouldn't the same approach implemented in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/830634/ be applied here too then? Or is the initialization of such objcts (the call to API()) not going to happen so frequently to justify caching the result of foo.API()?

Are you sure this is needed? I have initscripts-config included without this


root@localhost:~# apt list | grep initscripts

WARNING: apt does not have a stable CLI interface. Use with caution in scripts.

root@localhost:~# apt-cache depends initscripts

  Depends: lsb-base

  Depends: openrc
  Recommends: e2fsprogs
  Recommends: psmisc

root@localhost:~# apt-cache depends initscripts-config
initscripts-config
  Depends: systemd
  Depends: initscripts

Because zeroconf is not default on Debian as it is on CentOS.
In the CentOS initscripts-config package there is the file sysconfig-network.conf, which contains the line "ZEROCONF=yes", there is no such mechanism in Debian.
In debian, it needs to use the libnss-mdns, that is why we override the nsswitch.conf file to add "hosts:          files mdns4_minimal [NOTFOUND=return] dns mdns4".
Enabling zeroconf was in the scope of initscripts-config on CentOS so we kept that on Debian.

Sorry, still not clear to me what is requiring the zeroconf related packages? I don't have a problem building/installing an ISO with the initscripts packages. So are there runtime errors that I'm not noticing? Do we need to update the initscripts-config package dependendencies?

Yes, this is actually needed for the zeroconf, libnss_mdns:
https://packages.debian.org/bullseye/libnss-mdns. 

This was first sent in this old review:
https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/tools/+/817691

There I specified which ones were zeroconf related:

initscripts-config:

avahi-daemon 0.8-5 (zeroconf)
bind9-host 1:9.16.15-1 (zeroconf)
bind9-libs 1:9.16.15-1 (zeroconf)
initscripts 2.96-7
insserv 1.21.0-1.1
libavahi-core7 0.8-5 (zeroconf)
libdaemon0 0.14-7.1 (zeroconf)
libnss-mdns 0.14.1-2 (zeroconf)
libeinfo1 0.42-2.1
librc1 0.42-2.1
openrc 0.42-2.1

Maybe better in the commit message I put the same "(zeroconf)" information for the ones related to it. Would that be ok?

A simple if not backend_name: backend_name = 'SPDK' or other equivalent syntax should do.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I understand the requirement for this, but how about implementing it as a network attribute? i.e. for a network called mynet you would set a variable called mynet_no_ip: true. Then we could skip the task in ansible/ip-allocation.yml when this is set.

A benefit of that approach is that you could set the variable as a group_var, rather than per-host. It's also not very friendly to edit network-allocations.yml.

Good proposal, but my change skip the partial IPs, some IPs for other hosts still needed.
Your idea, I think, should be realised as a new change. For now we already use this patch in production.
A problem with this patch is that it would allow invalid IP addresses to exist in network-allocations.yml
no problem, we can add the additional variable to switch the defaults and enable - this will protect
Thanks a lot for changing the approach. I just made some small rewording / reformatting changes.

ansible/ip-allocation.yml.message:
My proposal was a bit different. We would have a no_ip attribute for the network, which could be added as a host or group var.

Then here, we could have:

  - not item | net_no_ip | bool

No changes required for the ip-allocation role.

the Mark's proposal is the another place for configuration - inventory, instead of configuration file network-allocation.yml. the workflow is the same, each time a new host is added you still need to run ip-allocation.

I don't think it's too complicated - it reuses existing patterns. Typically the necessary group_vars file would already exist.

It also means we can be explicit about which network we do not want to allocate an IP address on. Conversely, in your approach, by setting the flag we are putting the host in a mode that skips validation of IPs for all networks.

If I understand correctly your patch, each time a new host is added, you would need to run ip-allocation, then replace any auto-generated IP by an invalid value.

I agree with Mark: setting a global/group/host variable for each network is much cleaner and would allow to run the IP allocation as usual. You would normally use the same IP allocation pattern for all hosts in a group, wouldn't you? (e.g. all compute hosts having no IP on bridge brfoo)
Mark, I completely rewrite all the code to realise Your proposal.

Very interesting proposal, but it is much more complicated for configuration and adds too many points of failure, the mistake can be in the inventory directory names, in the files inside them, also when there are many hosts it is hard to manage all this. This requires no changes for the ip-allocation role but requires a new Jinja filter for the Ansible.

My solution is simple, all in one, easily manageable, there is one configuration file for all hosts.

environments/lifecycle/upgrade-prepare.y.message: I assumed we can skip this override for the upgrade-converge env file?..

I believe I got from the docs link that the setting is "sticky" at instance creation time. So, for the sake of argument, if the configured type is X, I create an instance, change the config to Y, "server rebuild" the instance, the machine type would still be X.

What still needs clarification though is what happens for users who have specifically set the NovaHWMachineType parameter to a different value than what you're setting here? Aren't we overwriting their desired configuration, and wouldn't this be unexpected for new instances they create in the future?

what about the case where a user has this set to some other value, would it matter? is it also only set on the instance at instance create? what if you "server rebuild" and the configured nova value has changed, what happens?

Based on my reading of https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/hw-machine-type.html#update, the workflow needs to be:

- update to latest nova-compute version
- restart nova-compute (this sets hw_machine_type for any instance where it is not set)
- configure hw_machine_type in nova.conf

it seems it would be enough to modify puppet tripleo profile defaults for it, for Train only. That would fit all the described scenarios, including a user with a custom value for NovaHWMachineType which must be retained

the intended upgrade semantics are as follows

for clean deployment we shoudl use the new default which use the Q35 machine type on x86

for upgrades we should use the value that is currently being used on the cloud being upgraded and then as a post action the operator shoudl update there config to the new default.

where an operator has already overridden the default that should take precidnece and still be applied.

the reason this is being done is that support for the PC machine type is expected to be removed in rhel/centos in the future.

with my downstream hat on the pc machine type is deprecated in osp 17(stable/wallaby) and unsupported in osp 18(stable/zed) and will be removed from qemu (tenitivly) in rhel 10

so the intent is to have operators opt in to the new default after they upstrade
and maintain the stable/wallaby(osp16.2) default until after the upgrade is complete. new deployment should use the new Q35 machine type from the start.
where an override has been set by an opterator that should still take precidence.
im not sure how to express that in ooo but that is what we intended to be implemented.

OpenStack's response when creating aggregates does not contain a "hosts" field [1] and OpenStack SDK thus uses the default value for hosts which is None [2].

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
So, overall I'm impressed with the formatted output and the resulting documentation changes when using the extension. A few nitpicks inside. It would be helpful to understand how you envisioned the example json data to be maintained. From a post standpoint, it is much more "practical" documentation in my mind, but from a normal everyday developer standpoint it feels like duplication of existing examples. I guess I'm also curious how you generated them upfront.

This will need to be updated

https://github.com/starlingx/integ/blob/master/centos-debian-compat/source/stx/systemd/85-debpkg-issues.preset#L46

If we merge this commit but do not update that integ file, then the debian env will encounter an error
As usual - what happens when somebody has old version of the inventory - without the new group? Will it fail?

As you can see in https://50a68c9f12fa1a0c2d14-09748fb7f50c6f484aea83154b0e91bf.ssl.cf5.rackcdn.com/833167/1/check/kolla-ansible-centos8s-source-prometheus-efk/349f1ee/primary/logs/ansible/deploy-prechecks the inventory precheck would fail, alerting the deployer that they need to amend their inventory.

As this must be a common situation for backports, is there a standard solution for it? IMHO we could add a warning to the upgrade section of the release note, would that be o.k. for you? Or do you think that a solution that does not depend on the existence of this group is required?
Glad Michal was on the lookout for troubles. :-)

We could do groups.get('prometheus-libvirt-exporter', []) which would return an empty group instead of failing on non-existent group - just like we did for back porting octavia-driver-agent (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/782735/14/ansible/roles/octavia/tasks/check-containers.yml#12).
Used this for the precheck and also made the exporter disabled by default.
It will. Also, we should probably change the default to "no" so that stable branch users don't get this by default.
Note operators may not run prechecks on each redeploy - they are often run on the initial one and then on upgrades.

validations_libs/cli/run.py.message:
Beware, it would be "localhost," in case of a string. At least, that's how I pass such an "inline inventory".

It may be better to use another method, such as pathlib, or plain os.path.isfile() in order to avoid checking cases where a user passes some other arbitrary string.
maybe a "if not parsed_args.inventory.startswith('localhost')" would allow to 100% cover this?

Yes that's why the check is made on 'localhost' which is the default "inventory" we use for the arg. But checking if the file exists wouldn't cover all cases either.

If file doesn't exist it can be because:
1. We are not dealing with file but an inline inventory.
2. The path points to where the inventory should be, but there isn't one.
3. The path is malformed, because someone messed up. 

Differentiating between them is problematic as it requires knowing what the operator intended.

I can implement some sort of check for things that look like a path, but it's going to be hacky. I can perform the check for file existence, thus taking care of 1. and 2. But that won't cover the case 1.

This call is just to ensure the file is accessible (i.e. exists + readable) and is a correct YAML format, right? Do we really want to do this? os.path might be better, and we can let Ansible manage the actual issue if the inventory is wrong?

Yes it's just for that. I don't want to really leave this up to ansible because we are calling ansible runner rather late and once per validation.

If the operator were to run just one validation at the time it wouldn't really matter, but if they were to run entire group there could be number of subsequent errors and a delay before the error would become apparent.

This way we can catch bulk of the problems before any actual validation processing starts, and that way save some time. 

There is also another reason. If we handle the issues in our code we have control over the reporting and we know what kind of situations will trigger the error. If we leave it to ansible runner the behavior might change without us noticing, causing a headache.

tests/unit/test_gitlab_driver.py.message:
I think this is correct because it won't cause any immediate action (we are already settled), and this way any changes that are effected by the config update (I don't think there are any, but it's theoretically possible) would not cause jobs to be held.

In short: the other way would probably be fine for this, but this way might be a smidge more correct (and better for future copypasta).
Should this happen after the config update to ensure we don't race the next timer trigger?
